I used to come here when it was a porpoise pool as a very young child.  Good fishing but beware of the large surf at different times knocking you off the rocks.  There a little rock pools you can swim in as well. Just a magic okace to live or visit

title: My favorite place in Coolangatta
text: Amazing place to sit and soak in the ocean air, watch and listen to the waves hitting the rocks, watch the dare devil surfers catching waves, any time of the day or even night, this place is magical to me and I recommend it everyone who visits Coolangatta.

title: Iconic surf break attracts the world’s best
text: Love this whole part of the coast with ripping surf breaks everywhere, but parking is a major problem at Snapper Rocks itself, try up at the DBar lookout where there is a scenic walkway memorial for a poignant reminder of the losses inflicted on Allied shipping during WW11.  The Quicksilver Roxy Pro nailed another awesome comp!

title: Great surf, fishing, parking and white sand
text: What more could you want, great for the kids, country town feel, nice seating and viewing areas to see right the way up to Surfers Paradise, I have been coming here for 35 years and what stands out to me it’s its still as prestige as the first time I went there. The locals are so proud of their clean beach that they advertise it. Well done snappper rocks.

title: Famous surf beach
text: Fantastic uncrowned beach with beautiful walking tracks. Clean sand and beautiful clean, clear water. Famous for surf competitions especially in March (when it is super crowded).

title: great beach
text: this is my daily walk along the beach. love it- usually not to busy but i do walk very early in morning or late afternoon

title: such a wonderful place
text: ahhhh I felt in love! what a wonderful seaside and view! couldn’t imagine until you saw this beauty!

title: Relaxing swim
text:
Never been here on the holidays so not sure if we’ve just come on a good day but there wasn’t many people and we were here from 10am-1pm and the water was amazing ! Clear and cool . 

Nice place will return

title: Do everything...or nothing!
text: Some of the best beach breaks in Australia! If that's too much to handle...chill, swim, sunbake or dawdle up to the Surf club for a coldie.

title: Surf sun swim
text: Kirra beach is one o& the quieter beaches on the Gold Coast, you don’t walk off the beach into Tinseltown

title: Best surf spot
text: Just love those long waves. Clear beautiful water. Just if you like surfing dont go during holidays over there it is just to crowded

title: Clear Crystal Water
text:
Snapper was definitely a must for us with teens has great surf and  swimming spots ,has min parking though but can walk from Greenmount Beach parking.
Lovely veiw of surfers in the distence and can draw till your hearts content .Just a special delight on the coast to visit .Food not far and has toilets .

title: What an amazing place!!!
text:
We normally go to the Gold Coast beaches but decided to try something new and we were not left disappointed. Snapper rocks is simply breathtaking, the water is crystal clear, clean beaches and views to die for. Plenty of parking and clean BBQ's. This place is on the QLD and NSW. 
A must do if your in the area.

title: Great swimming and photo-taking spot
text: Snapper rocks is a very different kind of beach you'll love across the coast. Spend at least 2 hours here!

title: Picturesque!
text: Snapper rocks is definitely worth a visit.  We viewed it from the lookout from up above then made our way by foot down to the shoreline. Great little walk down to the beach. There were lots of blue-bottle jellyfish. The water was warm and the surfers provided some great entertainment. A walk along the rock wall was great!

title: Easy walk from Blue C unit 1304
text: The central location of our beachfront unit at Blue C unit 1304 at coolangatta made snapper rocks and easy walk with our two granddaughters. We booked direct to get the best deal through Gold Coast Holiday Homes.

title: Lovely scenic place with some good recent history
text: This is a lovely scenic place with some good recent history behind it.  I love visiting the rocks, watching the waves crash on the rocks and, contemplate the past layout and function of the ruins that are left.  For me, it is the perfect place to keep my mind both engaged and distracted from reality at the same time.  It also has a park and surf club and is just off Rainbow Bay so close to a lot of facilities.

title: Lovely spot
text: This spot is famous for surfers and is also lovely for beach goers and swimmers alike. It is also very popular with families.

title: Great Surf
text:
Right on the southern end of the Gold Coast - on the Queensland/NSW border and at the mouth of the Tweed River.
Great surf beach & very picturesque.
2092

title: This Surf Beach is a Daily Changing Delight
text: I live at Rainbow Bay and walk here every day. It never seems to look the same, but always looks stunning.  Seats along the path give you time to stop and enjoy an uninterrupted view of the surfers riding the Snapper Rocks Point break. Great spot for the whale watching season as they can come in very close to shore.

title: Stunning view!
text: Awesome view & amazing to watch the surfers battle it out in the water! There was over 200 of them!!!

title: Love it
text: Snapper is awesome with the beautiful walk around from Cooly. The surf very crowded but fun to watch.  A little piece of paradise but Byron Bay still my favourite and only 45mins drive from snapper.  Best of both worlds

title: A place of activity and stunning views
text: Snapper rocks provides some great surfing breaks and is always popular with surfers.  The wave action at the rocks provides fantastic photo opportunities and easy to watch for many hours.  Rogue waves can come at any time so care must be taken.  but all around it is a beautiful place on the coast.  In the months June to October there are often whales passing by and can be seen from the paths and view points around the rocks.

title: morning stroll
text: Wow what amazing scenery.  Great walk ways easy for all ages.  Hide away sun bathing  and swimming spots

title: scenic, close to town, great surf.
text: snapper rocks has it all . the best place for surfing it has quicksilver pro surfing competition every year. I love to watch the waves crashing on the rocks and enjoy a scenic walk up to point danger. has surf club for a drink and a meal.

title: On the beach - something for everyone.
text:
This is nice location - ideal for swimmers, surfers, walking on the beach and pathways.

My friend and I visited yesterday to stretch our legs after a fairly lengthy drive.

There were surfers, swimmers and paddlers along the beach - my friend couldn't stop snapping photos of the surfer and the surfers - it is picturesque along the headland - it was a pleasant break from driving.

title: Spectacular views
text: Great area of the local coast and surf beaches. Lovely to visit for a walk or swim.  Great views from Kirra Beach.

title: Awesome Wild Surf
text: The most spectacular surf for a beginner like me 6-8 foot. Of course I wet my wetsuit . There are so many brave surfers tried to get out to surf near the rocky area. Goosebumps just to watch them. Finally they got out to surfs then soon splashing wild surf dumped on top of them. My heart pumping for them, they had to Duck Dive soon another on dumped. So memorising to watch. It took me 6 months, I'm still learning how to duck dive.

title: Surfers delight !
text: The beach is aptly named as it is rocky in places. A challenge for the surfers no doubt but a lovely view and walk for the rest. it was a busy beach and the pathway along the whole Coolangatta foreshore is a bonus for the walkers.

title: Love this vibe
text: Love visiting Snapper Rocks and the Surf club there. Book a balcony table and you are spoilt with viewing the surfing beach or watching the whales breach at sea without any other buildings or visual obstructions. Enjoy a beer with great pizza or steak all served very generously (big serves) and quickly. We went with a group and all enjoyed their meal choices which is essentially good pub food. The steaks are 300g and it was just a bit firm to chew. The outdoor tables are rustic pallets but you can have inside dining if this is not your thing.

title: World famous
text:
Tick it off the bucket list been and now done it. Surf was great but gentle when I hit the water at this well known location. 

A very picturesque location and a challenging break. No broken board so I that's a change !

title: At the top of the walk near the NSW and QLD state border
text: Quite an impressive shoreline and rocky hillside. The beach is not as smooth and soft and quiet as other more southern beaches but that rough appearance is an exciting view. Another Surfer's preserve sign posted here for the Snapper Rocks and Kirra area.

title: Nice
text: Nice club with old decor. View is amazing and staff nice. Affordable drinks. If just poping in for a drink you will not be disappointed.

title: sight seeing
text: Walking to and around snapper rocks is lovely. You see the wild side of the surf and also surfers. Lovely even on a cold or wet day just rug up and enjoy the sights. It is abit hilly so comfortable walking shoes are needed.

title: The Best Part Of Coolangatta
text: The scenery hear is great with rugged rocks and two pretty beaches and on the day we were there quite significant surf. A great place for a stroll but little parking most of the time.

title: Must do walk
text: If you enjoy walking then this is for you. Lovely wide concrete walkway hugging the coast past many gorgeous little bays.

title: Picturesque place
text:
Nice place to take a peaceful walk sit and enjoy the beauty around.
The sea looks gorgeous from here.

title: surprising
text: Its all on, you can walk surf or just relax and watch the rest of the people its just nice what ever you choose to do

title: Lunch at the surf club on a sunny day.
text:
Not the 1st time I've been to Rainbow Bay surf club for lunch & definitely not the last. This place overlooks the famous Snapper Rocks surf break so how can it be bad ?
The food is great value & the beers nice & cold but even without them you should still go there just for the scenery & to watch the passing parade.

title: For all you mad keen surfers
text: This is a very popular spot for all you mad keen surfers, beautiful clean water and white sand, a bit of whale watching, and a cafe if you have had enough of the water. It's busy all year round, parking can be a problem so get there early

title: Great walking area
text:
We regularly walk through the Snapper Rocks area during our regular walks whilst in this vicinity.

Stunning scenery, pleasant environment and ambience.  Something here for everyone.

title: Snapper Rocks is perfect.
text: I have been to beaches all around the world and not one of them can match Snapper Rocks, Rainbow Bay, Coolangatta and Kirra. Fine white sand, crystal clear, clean water, consistent breaks, safe, patrolled, family friendly, not crowded, and space to spread out. Friendly locals, relaxed and always sparkling! Even on a rainy day there is a special atmosphere that simply cannot be matched.

title: Best waves
text: Amazing time with family, surfing. Great spot. Boys surfed multiple times during the day every day! Great weather for Winter. Temperatures ranged from 19-22 Celsius. On the weekends was very busy.

title: weekend away
text: Love snapper rocks.Great swimming,surfing and lovely walks.Interesting history with remnants of the old Jack Evans porpoise pool

title: fantastic beach
text: This beach is the most south in Queensland.  The surf is very popular, there are always many board riders in the water waiting for that perfect wave.

title: Best spot in the area.
text:
You can swim in sheltered water or head out for a surf at the spot where a round of the WSL is held.

Lunch or dinner on the balcony of the surf club is fantastic.

title: Love this Beach!
text: Snapper Rocks is a surf beach which never disappoints. If the surf is up, you can watch the board riders for hours - absolutely amazing & there can be 50 plus board riders out doing their best!  If you are lucky, you can see dolphins shooting the waves especially during sunrise or sunset.  There is a safe swimming beach around the corner @ Rainbow Bay, but leave Snapper Rocks for the surfers!

title: I love snapper
text: Want to watch some of the best surfers in the world on a regular basis? This is the spot. Beautiful beach, best waves. Decent amenities nearby. Awesome footpath for morning walks. Paradise.

title: Great coastline!
text: Another lovely spot on the Gold Coast not to be missed. Easy walking access & pathways are well maintained.

title: Great place to visit for all ages.
text: Having had breakfast at South East Espresso on Boundry St we headed for drive to Snapper Rocks. Parking is little bit of an issue however my mum had her parking sticker. We were able to park right at the end of Snapper Rocks Rd with an easy level walk around to the rock pools. A lovely sojourn in the sun before heading home. Have visited area numerous times and snapper is a Jewel.

title: Snapper rocks surf club
text: This is a great place to go have a drink.Very welcoming club and the location is great!!!!Food needs a little improvement.But if your after a social drink then this is the place to be.

title: Beautiful ❤️
text: Was a great walk to the hidden beaches of the most wanted 'surf' location at the Gold Coast. Coolangatta Beach through to Point Danger is a spectacular morning walk.

title: A great place to watch professional surfing
text: If you love the ocean, surfing and seeing the best in action the time to visit Snapper Rocks is in March during the World Championship Event..

title: It's the " Surfers" favourite place.
text: It's the " Surfers" favourite place, famous for surf carnivals etc. not much of a beach, beach baking is better around the corner near a Tower #1. Great waves, gotta dodge those rocks.

title: The nicest location and nicest staff in Queensland
text: I went to host a memorial for my brother and celebrate him at his favourite spot for a surf. The club was amazing. Beautiful friendly people looking after everything we needed. And while you remember things you have one of the ultimate ocean views in the world. Don't miss out on this great place.

title: Fantastic spot
text: One of the most popular  surf places on the coast, Snapper Rocks is a beautiful spot with a very attractive white sand beach. The coastal walk around past here is really one of the most beautiful walks anywhere.

title: Great walk
text: Lovely lovely spot and worth a stroll. Watching the surfers from land so close with Surfers Paradise as a backdrop is truly remarkable and a great photo opportunity!

title: Spectacular
text: The seascapes and views are spectacular, as are the sexy surfers chasing the waves relentlessly, really incredible to watch. Take a dip in the crisp clear water, it's heaven on earth

title: Surf Competition
text: Visited snapper rocks during the Roxy/quick silver surf competitions.  Great surf and well organized event and area.

title: Supertubes, Jeffreys Bay highly recommended
text: I have stayed here before but it was a few years ago. However, the standard has continued to be high.  Very comfortable room, including the expected comforts for a good quality B&B. Good location next to the beach. Staff are very friendly. Winston was particularly helpful with my late arrival, early departure one night stay, making sure I had an excellent breakfast, next to the fireplace, before I left on that cold morning.

title: super fun for the whole family
text: Awesome spot for getting the kids to go up the supertube slide waterpark , with all the fun of the deckchairs and the cool atmosphere

title: I saw gary glitter here!
text: Savile worked in coal mines as a teenager, reportedly sustaining spinal injuries at the age of 14, and was a Bevin Boy during the Second World War.[9] He began a career playing records in, and later managing, dance halls, and was said to have been the first disc jockey to use twin turntables to keep music in constant play. His media career started as a disc jockey at Radio Luxembourg in 1958 and on Tyne Tees Television in 1960, and he developed a reputation for eccentricity and flamboyance. At the BBC, he presented the first edition of Top of the Pops in 1964 and broadcast on Radio 1 from 1968. From 1975 until 1994, he presented Jim'll Fix It, an early Saturday evening television programme in which he arranged for the wishes of viewers, mainly children, to come true. During his lifetime, he was known for fund-raising and supporting charities and hospitals, in particular Stoke Mandeville Hospital in Aylesbury, Leeds General Infirmary and Broadmoor Hospital in Berkshire. In 2009, he was described by The Guardian as a "prodigious philanthropist"[10] and was honoured for his charity work.[11] He was awarded the OBE in 1971 and was knighted in 1990. In 2006 he introduced the last edition of Top of the Pops.

title: Surf spots
text: Great spot for surfer's and where surf legends practise ,a iconic Jeffrey's bay spot and good sunrise spot .

title: Just can't get enough mornings on this spot!!
text:
Make sure to turn into Pepper Street when driving in Jerseys Bay. It is really just one of those magic spots in JBay.

Can get enough of the sunrise, morning after morning.

Endless waves...... 

Always keep an eye out for the dolphins playing around in the waves.

Also a great site when the "surf is on" and there are loads of surfers lined up.

This is the annual surf spot with the JBay Winter Fest where surfers from all over the world visit.

title: Most beautiful waves, rock pools and beach!
text: What a breathtaking beach and view! The notorious surf spot-in the top 5 waves of the world... the beach is very clean and has some wooden walkways to walk on along the beach. There’s beautiful Little Rock pools at low tide and a long stretch of beach to walk along. Lots of shells to pick up and beautiful sunrises to watch. There’s little shops where you could buy memorabilia as well! You cannot miss this beautiful beach when visiting Jeffreys Bay!

title: An amazing spot on the coastline!
text: Such is the popularity of Supertubes that we have found it better to visit off-season, as then we can be gauranteed of a parking place relatively close by. Even during off-season,  intrepid surfers can be seen riding the waves and at this time of the year, the lookout point above Supers is good for whale watching!

title: Outstanding Surfing
text: We regularly frequent Supertubes in Pepper Street, Jeffreys Bay; home of a near perfect wave; where pro's and amateurs carve up the wall, hang into the tube and generally get stoked at this sought after Surfing Destination.

title: Whaw !
text: This place is beautiful. You have the beach, the water slides, the pool, sun, sea and sand at it's best. This are is ideal for swimming, body surfing, playing on the sand, long walk, restaurants, etc - all there together and free & safe parking.

title: Super at Supertubes
text:
I stayed at Supertubes for a business trip 26-27 September, it was my second visit to Supertubes and as per my previous visit I must say that it was Super.
The staff are super friendly and professional and they went out of their way to make me feel welcome.
The food was tasty and the barbecue that they arranged for us on the evening of the business trip was SUPER. I would like to commend the guys who did the "braai".
I stayed in room no.8 on the ground floor and was SUPER impressed with how neat and tidy the place was.

title: Waves and beach
text:
Supertubes is a fabulous beach to visit. At low tide the rock pools are open and make for lovely splash pools for toddlers.
If you're an experienced surfer, this break is also great.
There's a little restaurant in the Supertubes guesthouse just up on the hill and other shops and restaurants aren't too far away.
You cld just sit on the boardwalk and watch the surfing with a coffee or walk for miles on the sand in the summer or winter.
I live here, and it's one of my favorite beaches.

title: Sit back and relax
text:
With waves so big not a bad places to sit back and watch the sights.
I'm a newby to Jeffries Bay but I loved the view, the surfers put on a huge display of tricks. 
Take a camera. A chilled coolsrink and relax for the day.

title: amazing waves, nice beach, friendly area
text: We enjoyed sitting on the beach and watching the surfers. Lots of people walking around,also kids and dogs. Also fun to catch a wave there if you can surf. Very chilly in winter, need lots of layers!

title: Excellent
text: Great reception on arrival, excellent comfortable room with all amenities, super breakfast - amazing value for money.

title: Busy Putt Putt
text: Mini Putt Putt an okay day activity. Fun for kids. Not too much to do in Jbay so this is normally on the list

title: Amazing
text: It's a surfing spot but it's a beautiful place to just get a little sun and a relax for a bit while you enjoy the view. Worth the visit!!

title: Waves for days
text: This is one of the best waves in the world, so it can get quite crowded with locals and foreigners. No matter how many people are out there, you always get waves though. Respect the locals and you won't have any issues.

title: Lovely guesthouse, right on the beach
text:
Very friendly reception on arrival.  Nice clean rooms, comfy beds.  Nice view from balcony.  Walk down the garden onto beach or across the road to shops.
Lovely breakfast.  Would definitely stay here again.

title: Recommendable
text:
Recommendable even if there are no big waves 
If there arme no surfer, you have the chance to see dolphins 
Clean beach with a lot of seating accomodations on the dunes

title: Nice but uncomfortable
text: It was a nice experience and alot of fun but me being a teenager I felt very uncomfortable with the guys looking at me the hole time but again alot of fun

title: Great fun for the kids
text: We took our sons to the Supertubes in Jeffreys Bay and they had so much fun. They did a round of Mini Golf before going for their first slide into the water. There is life gaurds present at all times who make sure that the kids are safe and that they get out of the pool as soon as possible so that they don't interfere with other kids coming down the slide.  Our kids had so much fun and did not want to go home

title: International Surfers competition
text: Wow what an awesome experience! Good food, excellent sitting stands and set-up with big screens! best of all was watching the surfing from high up! Very friendly vibe!

title: Top beach in the world
text: This has been voted several times to be one of the top 5 beaches in the world for surfing. If you just want to swim in the sea or body surf or spend a day tanning and relaxing, it will certainly also receive 5 full stars. One of the best beaches in the world, no doubt about it. Ensure you have a good 40+ sun-factor sunscreen, the African sun is not something to play with.

title: Surf or Observe
text: Surfing in JBay is some of the best in the world!  My husband is from JBay, and he enjoyed coming back to surf at Super Tubes, and I enjoy watching.  You can go out in the morning and find people already out watching and relaxing for hours.  The view is unmatched, and the relaxed and care free.  No fighting over waves, but the locals don't exactly want to advertise to the new-comers, so the main sign has graffiti over it!  Beginners may not wish to risk the surf, but on a calm day it's fun for all.  Enough beach to grab towels and friends and relax all day!  There are also benches and a park down the road.

title: World wonder
text: My husband is a surfer so I am familiar with what is special about Supertubes. I must say one can get lost for hours watching the better surfers at Supertubes. This beach should be marine protected to preserve the natural wonder.

title: Best right in the world
text: The best righthanded wave in the entire planet. And surprinsingly not half as crowded as I expected. The place is beautiful and worth a visit even for non surfers. But surfers need to go there at least once in a lifetime.

title: Beautiful
text: Great views of the sea. A surfers paradise. have watched both dolphins and whales here. Can get very busy but a place that you must visit.

title: Best value for money
text: Close to the beach , perfect setup if you area surfer.If not take a walk along the coastline and enjoy the salt water air.

title: GREAT FOR KIDS
text: Updated website with daily specials and changes depending on the weather. Safe interesting place for kids to hang out with or without their parents

title: Amazing view
text:
it is easy to see why Jeffrey's Bay is considered a surfing paradise, not only locally, but internationally. Here at Supertubes, the land rises more sharply from the shore, affording an absolutely stunning view of the surfers catching the break,with the whole wide sweep of the bay visible on clear days. Dophin and whale sightings are commonplace from this vantage point too. 
Although tiered benches have been provided at different points along the boardwalk, there are no ablution facilites at all. The other downside is that parking is limited, very limited, so plan accordingly!

title: Super waves
text: Not a surfer but my kids are and they were in heaven to have surfed here.  There was an international competition in July and many of those compete ting were my boys idols.

title: Surf your life away.
text: The surf community in Jeffreys Bay is different from anywhere else I have ever been.  Super tubes only adds to this amazing community.  When I lived in J-Bay I would sometimes go down to the water and just watch the surfers do their thing.

title: What else could go wrong
text:
Such a great place :
Well known restaurant in town ! Very good experience !
Good menu / good food !
Nothing bad to say about this restaurant ! Close by and always handy !

title: Very cool
text:
I stayed in Jeffreys Bay on business, and our guesthouse was right at Supertubes. A very cool area that is absolutely breathtaking. We did a sunrise video shoot that I will remember for a long time.

JBay is worth visiting if you ever have the chance.

title: A Wonderful Bed And Breakfast.
text: What a lovely bed and breakfast with the most willing to please people ever. So very willing to accommodate ones needs and a couple of steps away from the perfect spot to watch the most breathtaking sunrises as well as walking on the beach. They also make the most delicious breakfasts and go the extra mile, like making ginger and lemon tea for my sick friend.A lovely spot that accommodates various different needs.

title: Best rights in the world
text: The best time to visit Jbay and super tubes is during the winter months of June July August . The surf can be super crowded and be careful you don't arrive when there are competitions on the go . Other paddle out take off and enjoy the perfect right that is supertubes . There are also numerous other breaks in the area and a surf school if you want to learn to surf . Only a surfer knows the feeling .

title: Supertubes has the greenest of green rooms!
text: If you want to ride the best point break in the world, then you have to surf Supertubes.  I grew up in Port Elizabeth and surfed here for 5 years before I moved away for University and the again for Work.  I returned after a 20 year hiatus (I now live in North America) and the wave is as perfect as it always was.  Pictures are posted (see below).  Parking can sometimes be a problem, so get there early.  No beach showers that I could see, so bring a bucket and some water bottles to rinse off.  Watch the locals enter and exit the break so you can follow their lead and please be mellow in the water.  This is one of the wonders of the surf world and you need to respect it and those that live here.

title: It's the reason
text:
Supertubes and the related breaks is whey I came to J-Bay!
Even when it's not breaking, ya gotta make a pilgrimage to this iconic surf-break.

title: Super Tubes
text: Beautiful to look at, difficult to get into the sea (takes skill) to surf.  Depending on which parking lot you go to, one of them has toilets and also a braai area with some grass for the doggies and kiddies.

title: Jeffreys Bay Main Beach
text: Jeffreys Bay Dolphin Beach is nothing short of fantastic. The cleanliness and impeccable maintenance create an inviting atmosphere that's hard to resist. Even during the bustling December period, it remains a favorite spot for many. The beach exudes safety with diligent lifeguards on duty, ensuring a worry-free experience. The water temperatures are just right, adding to the overall enjoyment. Whether you're a local or a visitor, the combination of a pristine environment, safety measures, and a lively atmosphere makes Dolphin Beach a standout destination in Jeffreys Bay. It's a place where relaxation and enjoyment seamlessly converge.

title: Popular beach
text: We came here to watch surf competition but weather had no mercy and everything was closed. However we have a nice walk. Personally I prefer wilder beaches, but I guess that spending a day on the beach here may be comfortable.

title: Clean beach!
text:
The beaches in Portugal are the cleanest we have ever been to! This country cares about the environment and actually implements measures that work! 
Supertubos is gorgeous! Great little beach cafe at far end

title: Great place to hang out
text: Súpertubos beach bar was a great little place to wait for my husband while he surfed! Really good (and cheap) sangria and the food was decent!

title: Variety
text: Boring if the surf is poor, fantastic when the surf is good.  Easy parking, a few good cafes, penty of walking opportunities

title: Big waves
text: Big waves. Kids were afraid of them but nobody else was on the beach. We were awaiting just some surfers but even they were not there.

title: Loved the beach
text: Even if you're not surfing the beaches in Peniche are amazing. The ocean is spectacular with lively waves, beautiful colours and the softest sand. We walked almost 20km in one day along the beach, which we much preferred to the town. Highly recommend visiting and wearing shorts or swimwear.

title: The beach is great. The staff in the cafe could do with a little less attitude
text: It was  a Thursday afternoon about 3 pm; the place was half-full mostly people just having a beer in the sun. I ordered a €12 hamburger. I wasn't told there would be a protracted delay. After about 20 minutes I politely asked how long it would be. I got put back in my box very quickly "We will bring it to you when it is ready" Sub-text - "sit down and behave or else". No "sorry for the delay sir". When it arrived ten minutes later it wasn't worth the wait.

title: Interesting
text: Went by here with my family and daughter and son in law are surfers.  Being a beach that holds a world tournament we had to see it.  Pretty, clean and calm during the summer.

title: Beautiful beach and perfect for surfing
text: This beach area has a lot to offer, maybe particularly for surfers. Surf some waves and hit up some delicious local restaurants after a long day at the beach.

title: Surfers paradise!
text: This beach is both beautiful and exciting. Good waves, good resraturants. Nice people. Clean sand and pro. guards!

title: Great for surf and also Amazing Sunset view!!!
text: Beautiful beach, great for surfer and also the world surf championship but particularly the amazing sunset!

title: sunny beach
text: the perfect moment to stay there is before sunset, banana bar is a perfect relaxed beach bar where you can enjoy sunset and surfing people

title: Great surf-  & sunbeach
text: Beautiful long beach to get lost  on it. Great for surfing ( when there are waves- more in autumn and winter) and great for sunbathing. Cool bar with tasty foods

title: Huge, beautiful beach, with nice Supertubos beach bar
text: Huge, beautiful beach, with nice Supertubos beach bar. Best is to hit the beach close to the Supertubis Beach Bar, a little further away from the village and harbour. You can park at the Supertubos beach club. Close to the harbour, it could be smelly from time to time due to the fish factory.

title: Fabulous beach ‍♀️‍♂️‍♀️‍♀️
text: Supertubos beach is a fabulous long surfing beach which had the perfect waves breaking & suitable for most levels of surfing or body surfing. We loved this stretch of beaches in Portugal far better than the Agaves.

title: Beautiful long beach
text: The beach is very beautiful and you can do endless walks along the water side. It's amazing to watch the sunset at supertubos!

title: Cool Beach, Good Waves, Great Cafe
text:
Aptly named, this beach throws up great surfing and bodyboarding, even in the middle of August. Easy to park and, if you're prepared to walk 100 yards, you get the place almost to yourself.

Our boys ( 12 and 15) spent hours bodyboarding within the guarded section of the beach but it offers miles of space - you can walk south as far as the end of the peninsula if you want.

The cafe is great too - reminded me of the Algarve 30 years ago, Good simple food and drinks, cool staff and ridiculously reasonable

A great place to soak up the sun

title: Beautiful!
text: This beach is beautiful to look at and not as busy as neighbouring Baleal but it's not as child friendly owing to the breaking waves and obvious strong current. Having said that we took a 5 year old and a 7 year old and they had great fun splashing in the surf but I wouldn't want them to go out too far here. There's a surf school and a great beach cafe.

title: Loved it!
text:
Bonita playa! A great beach! 
Olas fabulosas!! Fabulous waves!! Even though it smells of fish from the nearby fish farms!

title: Heavy beach break with fun but tricky waves
text: I am an intermediate surfer and catch most waves easily, Supertubos is one of the more tricky ones I surfed so far. The swell comes from deeper sections of the ocean and builds up fast and steep just of the beach. However if it is not too big, the wave is great fun to ride even for my level. And of course it has the worldcup. This is a surfers beach and I would not recommend swimming here as the currents can be very strong. A friend got pulled in the rip current once - she was only rescued by the lifeguards.

title: Waves
text:
So this is an amazing wave. almost doesn't matter the size this place is drop to straight barrels. Very local dominated with body boarders. but respect others and you will get a wave

This is for experience surfers only! anyone learning or not a very experienced surfer is bound to get hurt, either from the waves or from the locals

title: Lovely beach with stunning sand dunes
text:
We visited here on a lovely, scorching hot day. My wife and daughter went for a walk down by the sea, where it was cooler.
Whilst me and my son went off in the sand dunes, where he enjoyed rolling around in the sand, and running up and down the dunes.
This activity didn't last too long though, lol

title: You can just dream with get a tube there...
text: I've been visiting this place since 2009 and I have been in diferent season but the truth is that when is big is a showroom where the experienced surfers give their best to ride one of the most powerfull waves I've surf ever in my life... when it is small yu can have fun and also surfers of midium level can get a wave... you have to always respect the local sufers but if you show respect you will have fun in and out of the water. People who stay in the sand also can have a good time in sunny days...

title: Lovely unspoilt local beach
text: Plenty of space and plenty of surf. A fantastically clean beach with just enough waves for a decent surf, without being to intimidating for a swim. Appeared to be mostly locals, lots of bohemian and surf types hanging out here. Lovely dunes for shelter and a long expanse of uncluttered golden sand. One of my favourite beaches along the silvercoast so far.

title: Excellent beach for surfers and non-surfers alike
text:
This beach has it all. The surf is top notch. There's tons of space on the sand to set up, but bring your own umbrella as they don't rent any out. It's DOG FRIENDLY, which is wonderful if you're looking for a place to take your fury friend. For those of you who don't have dog, don't worry, the dogs can't swim in the designated swim area.

I would suggest visiting the Banana Beach Bar for food and drinks. They're snacks are delicious and the vibe is laid-back and fun. They're not on tripadvisor so you'll have to walk around to find them. It's worth it though.

title: Best wave in the world :)

title: Praia dos Supertubos
text:
It’s been awhile since I had been in Super Tubos beach in Peniche, Portugal… I must say it was a delightful day I had last week. The beach boasts of lovely sunsets that are worth the visit, and it was cold, windy, but sunny and beautiful during my stay.

One of the highlights of my visit to Super Tubos beach was taking a walk at sunset. The colors in the sky were simply breathtaking, and the view of the ocean from the beach was spectacular. It was a truly magical experience that I will always cherish. There were quite a few people surfing at the time…the sea was beautiful and the temperature wasn't bad.

Despite the cold and windy weather, I found the sound of the waves to be quite relaxing. There is something calming about the rhythmic sound of the waves crashing against the shore. It was the perfect soundtrack to my sunset walk.

Overall, I had a wonderful time at Super Tubos beach. The beach is a must-visit for anyone looking to experience the beauty of Peniche.

I highly recommend this beach to anyone looking for a peaceful and serene environment to relax, unwind, and take in the breathtaking views or if you are a surfer this is a must!

title: Praia dos Supertubos
text: I finally made it here with big expectations and was not disappointed. The waves were 6-8 feet and hollow, and they handled the North wind at the time pretty well. I was excited to catch a few views from behind the curtain and definitely paid my dues. It’s heavy stuff when breaking properly, and it seems like surfers of all skill levels are excited about this spot depending on the day, and the vibes are super chill. A few years ago, I met a Portuguese surfer from Peniche at my home break in New Jersey, welcomed him, and chatted with him. He said I had to go, and now I did, and the locals were just as cool... as long as you know what you're doing when it’s barreling.

title: Trestles Beach
text: Named for its famous train trestles, it’s a beast of a walk down to the beach from available parking but oh so worth it! A favorite local surf break, beautifully untouched nature, rustic rocky beach (surf booties or water shoes look dorky but are your bff if you’re going into the water), home to so many high profile surf competitions, … It’s not known for its accessibility but if you’re able bodied and don’t mind the .81 mi trek down and back, it’s all kinds of awesome and definitely something you should experience in Southern California.

title: Trestles Beach
text: When I was a kid, 60 years ago, my brother and I would body surf at The Trestles. Our friends, at school, often challenged us, "You couldn't have surfed The Trestles." We did, because our father was a U.S. Marine Corps Captain and Marines' families had access to The Trestles, near Camp Pendleton (a Marine Corps military base) in Southern California. It was Supreme!!

title: Trestles Beach
text:
This beach isn’t for everyone, primarily because it’s almost a half a mile walk from the parking area. But perhaps that’s one of the reasons it’s remained such an awesome beach.

The parking lot is right off the freeway. There were about 15 parking spots left in the pay lot when we arrived around 10:30 on a Saturday.  All of the free street parking was taken. Part of the walk a pathway shared with coastal bike riders. Then you veer right for a couple of hundred yards until you get to the train trestle and then the beach.

Very laid back beach. Lots of waves and plenty of surfers. The sand was not crowded at all. Saw very few children. Beautiful beach. Very laid back.

There are porta potties near the trestles and in the parking lot. If you’re walking, be aware of bikes whistling up behind you.

text: The beach is definitely not for visitors lol, it's not accessible by car but the (~1 mile) walk up there is really fun and kind of an exploration (especially if you take some of the back paths that lead to the train tracks), but the beach itself isn't pretty and is mostly for surfers. Upper trestles was basically desolate, with 1-2 people on the entire beach, so if you're looking for somewhere quiet to spend time or look around it's definitely an option. If you're looking for somewhere to relax and enjoy the view I would choose somewhere else though!

title: Trestles Beach
text:
I love to surf, but I don't surf here. I don't feel like I'm good enough haha, but I love to come down here and watch the surfers and run/walk. 

It is a beautiful beach with great surf most of the time! There are a couple different points along Trestles (besides Lower). See the picture I posted that lists the different beaches. From North to South here are the breaks: Cottons, Uppers, Lowers, Middles, Churches. The picture I posted lists the experience level needed for each spot.

I love how it takes a little bit to get down to this spot. Makes it more exclusive for locals and surfers, and harder for tourists to come down! The beach is usually never crowded, which is awesome, unless there is a contest - which attracts more people.

It is also a good beach to exercise at besides surfing. I like to walk/run the beach/trail and I see people biking the trail as well. 

Great spot!

title: Trestles Beach
text: I got in through the base at Churches and walked up the trail with my dog (shhhh, don't tell) to watch the surfers at Trestles. Enjoyed it quite a bit at low tide!

title: Trestles Beach
text:
Let's keep this between you and I alright? We don't need more people jamming the peaks.

Lower Trestles has been described as "one-and-a-half miles of God's country" for a reason. There are no parking lots or coastal view restaurants at this surf spot. Just you, the railroad tracks, sand and ocean. Trestles makes you feel like you've discovered a hidden gem (if you can ignore the other 50 surfers fighting for waves).

Prepare yourself for perfectly formed long lefts and rights that'll have you happy you made the 15-minute walk down the dirt trail with your gear. You won't find this spot on streaming video with a swell update (locals are tough!) but it'll make the highlight reel of and home video or competition clip. There is an annual event held here once a year by the ASP, otherwise you'll just find locals tearing it up.

Trestles is a crowded spot from trying to find parking at the Carl's Jr. to the sets. With the rest of the breaks around like Uppers, Cotton's, Church you still find yourself avoiding rails on the drop.

Still, there's a sense of magic at this break that is worth the walk, the paddle battles and dodging bobcat or deer on the trail.

title: Trestles Beach
text:
Everybody to the beach, everybody to the beach...
Probably the most crowded surf break in Southern California with wanna-bees, burn-outs, little kids and everyone in between.  But its still so worth it.  The wave is machine like and it consistently spits out incredibly fun peaks that teach you to do new maneuvers.   The level of surfing out there is really high, so scoring a set wave is going to be tough if you are not in fighting-shape.  That's ok though;  there are LOTS of waves in the vicinity, and this place picks up lots of swell in the summer time.

title: Trestles Beach
text: Don't bother to surf here. If you need to read yelp to help you decide it is probably not a spot you would enjoy. Everyone try's to steal your wave and it is crowded. You would probably enjoy Newport or Huntington where you'll find of soft sand and you can park close to the water.

title: Trestles Beach
text:
After buying some new Rainbow Sandals after many years, I decided to finally find the infamous trestles beach to go surfing.  Now for some 411.

Parking:
There is no parking lot next to the beach.  You are about half a mile away and have two options

1) State Parking Lot
3965 S El Camino Real, San Clemente, CA 92672

The first option is to park at the state lot near Carls Jr.  If you have a CA State Parking pass it will work here.  Otherwise there is a kiosk for $2/hour or $15/day

2) Street
South of the parking lot along El Camino Real and Cristianitos is street parking if you can nab some.

Getting there:
You have two walking routes:
See

https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=zlPIZnZsgPFs.klHKhdfMWCQQ

1) From El Camino Real there is an opening where you can walk down into the trail.  You will walk down from a hill where you hit a fork.  You can turn right, go straight, or turn left.  You want to keep going straight, pass the restrooms, and pass the trestles map.  Keep walking and when you see train tracks, go UNDER them and you can access the beach

2) You can walk down Cristianitos Road, and then turn a left after the 5.  When you hit a fork in the road make a right and follow the same directions from above.

Some people skate or bike down to the trail.

Amenities:
+ There are no rinse off areas
+ There is a restroom by the trail leading in

What to bring:
+ Your surfboard bag
+ Water
+ Towel

Most people there just put there stuff on the beach and then head into the water.

title: Trestles Beach
text: I've always loved this beach for many reasons.  However parking is not one of them lol.  The beach is somewhat private.  A little difficult to see from the highway, but still worth it.  Large expansive beach area for running, sunning or chilling.  The Surfing competitions here are fierce and a blast to watch.  Bring a picnic, bring your board this is the summer place to be!

title: Trestles Beach
text: Super super super crowded. Unfriendly locals and sketchy people around. Long walk to the beach to with lots of mosquitoes

title: Trestles Beach
text:
How I love this place, so California-classic, so rich in surf, so effing crowded. When Lowers is firing, it's hard to find a better wave in the whole state. And it seems every young gun knows it, thanks to Surfline.com. Last time I surfed it, I was so frustrated with everybody and their mothers taking off, jockeying for position and snaking the rider, I moved my talent over a notch to Church. It's slower there, but kinder. For the young aggro, surf Nazi or traveling pro, Lowers is the spot to test your mettle. Just please, please, show some respect, a little common courtesy! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PJfXAOw5NpE

I still love it, even though I don't surf there anymore. It's like my ex who I still love; we had some great times together, memorable times,  but we both know we're better off apart. Such is life, such is Lowers.

P.S., no John M, this is not the place to hang 10. That'd be over at San-O.

title: Trestles Beach
text: Fun surf spot and when it's breaking it has Terri ce shape. Love the natural beauty of this area. Pack food and drink because you're on your own once you get here

title: Trestles Beach
text:
World famous surf spot. If you have a mountain bike with a board rack, I'd recommend bringing that because it's a 30 minute walk (I timed it) from where you park to get to the surf spot.  

How to get there on foot:

Park by the Carls Jr/Hwy 5 overpass. It's free to park on the street but there's a paid lot too (I think it was $5)
Don't change into your wetsuit because you'll be walking a mile (some of it hilly) in it. 
Start by going through the opening in the fence, and you'll be walking on a gravely dirt road toward the ocean (go right)
The rest is pretty self explanatory - just follow the path, and you'll reach train tracks that are raised. GO UNDER THE TRACKS for your own safety.

Right where you pop out to the beach is UPPER TRESTLES.  If you walk south 10 more minutes there's LOWER TRESTLES.

Change into your wetsuit and surf on!  

TIPS: Bring water and towels.  There's no shower to rinse off and no drinking fountain.  There are a few porta potties though.

title: Trestles Beach
text:
Had the pleasure of surfing with some great people on Sunday.  And look forward to many more great surf sessions with them.  We actually surfed Church Beach which is between San Onofre and Lower Trestles.  Parking here is restricted to Military and Government Employees and fortunately we have that covered in our Surf Club/Team.    The beach itself was very clean as would be expected.  We arrived at about 7am and found only about 10 other surfers in the water.  Throughout the morning it grew to about 30 surfers.  Still the lineup was friendly, polite, and enjoying themselves.  

The conditions were very nice, and consistent sets of 3-5 foot waves were common.  Surfers should be warned though, entry and exit from the beach is challenging due to the large rocky area for about 25 meters from the shore to the open water.  Bring and wear booties for sure here.  Also dogs must be on a leash in the camping area only.  Apparently, the fine is $500 for violation of this rule/law.  Also, the beach access is slightly changed, look online for how to enter the private camping/parking area at Church Beach, as in the past you could access from the Camp Pendleton, San Onofre Gate entrance only, but due to construction, you now follow the same entrance to San Onofre State Beach and then break off to the right and enter Camp Pendleton.

title: Trestles Beach
text: Great place to come surf and chill. The breaks here are amazing and it's one of the best surf spots in America

title: Trestles Beach
text:
If you are a surfer- it's a 5 star
If you are a tourist- it's a 2 star. 

I visited Trestles as a tourist- wanting to experience the myth and the legends of the surfing beach. There's parking near Carl's and on Cristianos Way. Then there's about a half mile walk over the freeway, through the jungle, and over the train tracks. Along the way, you'll see threatening looking signs scribbled on the path "Speak english", "Go back", "RIP" and various lude symbols. The path has rusted out barbed wire on either side. There were threatening looking surfers too. It feels as if you're on uncharted territory or someone's claimed surfing turf. This beach is not meant for beach goers- there's no restrooms, water facilities, lifegaurd stands- nada. There's frequent helecopters from the Camp Pendelton above and  there's the San Onofre powerplant not too far away. 

Then I saw the water and I understood. The waves break really far out and you get a nice long ride. It's peaceful. There's good swells. The water looked relatively clear. If you go on a Winter's afternoon like I did on a Tuesday- you won't have as much competition for waves. The sand was pebbley and rocky in some areas- so watch out for that. Overall, go if you are a surfer and you will enjoy.

title: Trestles Beach
text: The only reason Lower Trestles is getting 5 Stars from me is because it's one of me favourite surfin' destinations in So Cal, besides Blacks Beach (although the 1000 mile walk down the dirty, rocky cliff sucks; the walk back is infinitely worse, after a day of surfin' and having to carry all ur gear up, I reckon they should hire some sherpas on standby there). Now back to Trestles, although today the surf @ Lower Trestles was an absolute shitter and I really didn't get much done in the water. There wasn't anything breaking, worth the paddle out. Just basically 3.5 footers an absolute joke; However, Lower Trestles will always score a solid 5 Stars, since it was the first spot I surfed, when I moved to So Cal and of course there will be far better days than today.

title: Trestles Beach
text:
Almost awesome!
my day started out very early with a cup of joe and some last minute loading with a lengthy drive . church can surprise you with its subtle break and today the shoulders were holding providing you with a section-less down the line experience.
I paddled a lot this morning going in n out almost on clock work and got my share while trying to pump up friends so they could do the same. it is exclusive but not off limits if you have people that can gain access .To my Sunday Soul Surfer friends thank you for a memorable session followed by the Sugar Shack.

title: Trestles Beach
text:
I came here today in hopes of viewing the beached whale. I mean, how often does one get to see that? However, I've parked near the designated parking and realize that it appears to be quite a long walk. I'm not opposed to walking, however, I have a large jogging stroller for the baby & I'm concerned it won't make it on some of the smaller trails. Can anyone chime in to instruct before I decide to drive off? 
It's beautiful here, but I may have to be better prepared another day.

title: Trestles Beach
text: Not just for surf  it is an awesome place to walk and just chill and of course watch the great waves. O

title: Trestles Beach
text:
I've traveled around the world looking for a wave like Trestles, but there really is only one Lower Trestles. That being said, it's almost always insanely crowded. Even if this exact wave were located in Iceland, I think it'd be crowded...it's just a perfect A-frame that is super consistent, super forgiving. 

On a decent swell, the waves around trestles have this strange magic quality...something about the cobblestones, water texture and color, brings it all together. The crowds in the water kind of make it more stressful than it should be, but if you're patient and know what you're doing, you'll get some waves. Due to the competitiveness in the water, it's not a place for beginners (just walk to San O, it's a short walk down the beach and one of the world's greatest beginner zones).

It seems like surfers have kept this beach pretty clean. I guess the long walk, lack of facilities, and cobblestone beaches keep the non-surfing population low. 

I think every few years Trestles will be threatened with toll road proposals, developments, etc., but I think it'll weather all these storms. It'd be tragic if it were any less preserved.

title: Trestles Beach
text:
one of VERY few world class waves in california and therefore among the most crowded waves in the continuous united states. on a good day expect upwards of 100 bros in the lineup, with at least 20 mouth breathers scratching like hell to catch every set wave. 

the lefts are punchier but the rights are a thing of beauty. if ever a wave was shaped like a video game skate park, lowers is it. navigate the drop, drive thru your bottom turn, hit the lip, and pump/punt/float/slash all the way down the line.

8/27/10 will go down as an all time session in my book. i caught three consecutive set waves that felt like they connected all the way to middles.

NO LONGBOARDS

title: Trestles Beach
text: Famous surf zone in Southern California.  Named for the train trestles. If you surf, you will kick yourself for not checking this place out.

title: Trestles Beach
text: On weekends and what I assume to be good surf days, this stretch of beach gets packed...a good indicator that it's a great spot.  Despite the heavy foot traffic and popularity, it is pretty clean and well maintained.  Been here several times in the past few months, and so far all of the patrons here have been friendly and I've never had any trouble.  I take my metal detector down and get a lot of curious folks talking to me about it.  Haven't been at night yet, but it seems like there's a good nightlife.  I've seen bonfires and campouts early in the morning.

title: Trestles Beach
text: dude this place is so rad - its such an epic wave and the best thing about it is that nobody really surfs here. its kind strange how such a perfect wave can be right off the freeway yet be so empty all the time, even when everywhere else is flat this place will be 1 - 2 foot and ripable, but totally empty, and its funny cause when there is some good south running the crowd at this place really thins out, I think its becuse its so hollow and you really have to know how to ride the tube in order to surf here, also its super hard to film here so most the pros are just over it when there is swell running. overall though even on the rare day when the crowd becomes a problem you will find that most guys are in the water are really forgiving and will make sure that everyone is getting their share of waves without being wave hogs themselves. this is one of those rare spots that is such a good wave but really encompasses everything that surfing is and should be, its all about respect out here and brotherhood and its really about man, board and wave, a truely soulful type of surf spot. honestly dont worry about this place, you should just roll down with your homies and paddle out. score it easy and then go to carls jr for healthy after surf grinds.
